Color Entanglement in Hadronic Processes for Transverse
Momentum Dependent Parton Distribution Functions
M. G. A. Buffing * and P. J. Mulders †
Theory Group, Nikhef & Department of Physics,
Faculty of Science, VU University
De Boelelaan 1081, NL-1081 HV Amsterdam, the Netherlands
* m.g.a.buffing@vu.nl
† p.j.g.mulders@vu.nl
Published 25 February 2015
In the description of protons, we go beyond the ordinary collinear parton distribution
functions (PDFs), by including transverse momentum dependent PDFs (TMDs). As
such, we become sensitive to polarization modes of the partons and protons that one
cannot probe without accounting for transverse momenta of partons, in particular when
looking at azimuthal asymmetries.
Hadronic processes require the inclusion of gluon contributions forming the gauge
links, which are path-ordered exponentials tracing the color flow. In processes with two
hadrons in the initial state, such as Drell-Yan (DY), the gauge links from different parts of
the process get entangled. We show that in color disentangling this gauge link structure,
one becomes sensitive to this color flow. After disentanglement, particular combinations
of TMDs will require a different numerical color factor than one naively might have
expected. Such color factors will even play a role for azimuthal asymmetries in the
simplest hadronic processes such as DY.
Keywords: Drell-Yan; parton distribution functions; gauge links.
PACS Numbers: 12.38.−t, 13.85.Qk, 13.90.+i

1. Introduction
Transverse momentum dependent parton distribution functions (TMDs) are used to
describe the proton in momentum space when going beyond the collinear approach
by including transverse directions.
1–3 Whereas in the transverse momentum inte-
grated case only three distribution functions are present, namely for unpolarized
quarks in an unpolarized proton, f 1 (x), for longitudinally polarized (actually chiral)
quarks in a longitudinally polarized proton, the helicity distribution g 1 (x), and for
transversely polarized quarks in a transversely polarized proton, the transversity

as the Sivers function for unpolarized quarks in a transversely polarized proton.
It has a 'single-spin' nature and is time-reversal odd (T-odd). A special effect for
T-odd TMDs such as the Sivers function [4]–[8] is a sign flip between the Sivers
TMD as measured in the Drell-Yan process compared to the Sivers TMD as mea-
sured in SIDIS. This sign flip is in particular a consequence of the presence of gauge
links (Wilson lines), which are path-ordered exponentials connecting the (anti)quark
fields in the quark correlator and which assure color gauge invariance. In Section 2,
based on Ref. [9], we give an overview of these kind of universality issues for the
other quark TMDs as well. We show that also for the Pretzelocity function, a ten-
sor correlation for transversely polarized quarks in a transversely polarized proton,
process dependence is implied. Rather than having a potential infinite number of
these functions, one for each process, we show that three independent Pretzelocity
TMDs are sufficient, of which in principle different combinations appear in a given
process. For this study we use transverse moments.
In Section 3, based on the Refs. [10] and [11] we go one step further, by consid-
ering processes with multiple hadronic correlators, the simplest example of which
is the Drell-Yan process.
12 By again using transverse moments, we find an entan-
glement between the gauge link contributions, which manifests itself in specific
overall factors for those azimuthal asymmetries that involve combinations of TMDs
describing the quark distributions in two hadrons.

3. Color entanglement
In this section, which is based on the Refs. [10] and [11], we go one step further, by
looking at processes containing multiple correlators rather than just the individual
correlators by using transverse weighting with transverse moments the way we see
it.
In Ref. [29] is was shown for a specific quark-quark scattering diagram that color
entanglement occurs. For the diagram in this reference, this was a result of contri-
butions where two additional gluons coming from the parts that are associated with
the quark correlators couple on the hard scattering contribution. Since these gluons
carry color, the color flow is in such a way that the diagram cannot be disentangled
into a product of two quark correlators and a hard scattering contribution.
In our case, we focus on Drell-Yan as an example. In the Drell-Yan process, a
quark and an antiquark produce a virtual photon, which in turn produces something
else (e.g. a quark-antiquark pair). In the simplest description, where we ignore the
gauge link contributions, the cross section is given by

4. Conclusions
By using an analysis in terms of transverse moments, we can make an identification
between matrix elements and TMDs. As a result, some of the TMDs turn out to be
process dependent. However, despite this process dependence for some of the TMDs,
only a finite number of basic functions exists, with a calculable linear combination
of them appearing in any given process. This leads e.g. to the presence of three
Pretzelocity functions and (calculable) process-dependence of the p
2
T
behavior of for
instance the transversity functions, of which details will be given in a forthcoming
publication.
28
In hard scattering processes with two hadronic particles in the initial state, color
entanglement could occur for specific contributions to the cross section. This entan-
glement is a result of gauge knots that are 'stuck' on the specific external parton legs
in the diagram for the hard scattering process. After transverse integration, these
gauge knots usually are of no concern in the sense that they do not cause entan-
glement, but are absorbed in their respective hadronic matrix elements. However,
